articles.headline: South Korean Leader Boxed In as Trump Threatens North Korea
articles.snippet: President Moon Jae-in’s plans for easing tensions with North Korea have gone nowhere, and his supporters worry the Trump administration may drag their nation into war.
articles.abstract: President Moon Jae-in’s plans for easing tensions with North Korea have gone nowhere, and his supporters worry the Trump administration may drag their nation into war.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — He won the presidency promising a shift toward dialogue with North Korea. He argued that sanctions and pressure alone would never persuade the North to scrap its nuclear arsenal. And he pledged to “say no to the Americans if necessary.”
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and Motoko Rich

articles.headline: Twitter’s Panic After Trump’s Account Is Deleted Caps a Rough Week
articles.snippet: It was another fiasco that the social media company, which has been under scrutiny for online abuse and how its service can be misused.
articles.abstract: It was another fiasco that the social media company, which has been under scrutiny for online abuse and how its service can be misused.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 11 minutes on Thursday night, when President Trump’s Twitter account was unexpectedly disabled, Twitter went into panic mode.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: How Silicon Valley Plans to Conquer the Classroom
articles.snippet: Tech firms are deploying sophisticated marketing techniques to try to sell their wares into America’s schools.
articles.abstract: Tech firms are deploying sophisticated marketing techniques to try to sell their wares into America’s schools.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE COUNTY, Md. — They call it the “Church Lane Hug.”
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Bringing Accountability to the Wells Fargo Boardroom
articles.snippet: A federal judge’s ruling delivers a message to directors who are less than vigilant when monitoring a company for misdeeds.
articles.abstract: A federal judge’s ruling delivers a message to directors who are less than vigilant when monitoring a company for misdeeds.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s distressingly common for directors of public companies to skate away from liability when corporate misconduct occurs on their watch. That’s why a recent ruling by a federal judge hearing two cases against Wells Fargo’s officers and directors is both unusual and welcome.

articles.headline: As Sex Accusations Flood Social Media, Lawyers Gear Up for Suits
articles.snippet: Brett Ratner, a Hollywood director, sued a woman who accused him of sexual harassment. Some lawyers expect more such cases to happen, they said.
articles.abstract: Brett Ratner, a Hollywood director, sued a woman who accused him of sexual harassment. Some lawyers expect more such cases to happen, they said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Social media has overflowed with sexual misconduct allegations during the last few weeks. The 450-word post that Melanie Kohler put on Facebook probably had the shortest life — a few hours. It may also have been the first to get its author sued.

articles.headline: Women’s Whisper Network Raises Its Voice
articles.snippet: A behind-the-scenes support system in the workplace is gaining momentum in a digital age that allows women to share their experiences publicly.
articles.abstract: A behind-the-scenes support system in the workplace is gaining momentum in a digital age that allows women to share their experiences publicly.
articles.lead_paragraph: They called themselves the Glass Ceiling Club.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Detroit: From Motor City to Housing Incubator
articles.snippet: The 2008 financial crisis and 2013 city bankruptcy gutted Detroit’s housing market. Now, Detroit is experimenting with unorthodox ways to get people to buy homes and renovate houses.
articles.abstract: The 2008 financial crisis and 2013 city bankruptcy gutted Detroit’s housing market. Now, Detroit is experimenting with unorthodox ways to get people to buy homes and renovate houses.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, the country’s two largest banks, trace their roots in Detroit back decades, when they helped finance the city’s once-booming auto industry.

articles.headline: Smuggled, Beaten and Drugged: The Illicit Global Ape Trade
articles.snippet: The New York Times tracked international ape smugglers from Congolese rain forests to the back streets of Bangkok. Here is what unfolded.
articles.abstract: The New York Times tracked international ape smugglers from Congolese rain forests to the back streets of Bangkok. Here is what unfolded.
articles.lead_paragraph: MBANDAKA, Democratic Republic of Congo — The sting began, as so many things do these days, on social media.

articles.headline: Poised for West Coast Dominance, Democrats Eye Grand Agenda
articles.snippet: A special election in Washington State could give Democrats a free hand to enact liberal policies, including on climate, across the entire West Coast.
articles.abstract: A special election in Washington State could give Democrats a free hand to enact liberal policies, including on climate, across the entire West Coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAMMAMISH, Wash. — It is the stuff of liberal fantasies: a vast, defiant territory, sweeping along the country’s Pacific coastline, governed by Democrats and resisting President Trump at every turn.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: A Broke, and Broken, Flood Insurance Program
articles.snippet: Now, an unusual coalition of insurers, environmentalists and fiscal conservatives is seeking major changes in the federal plan as a deadline approaches.
articles.abstract: Now, an unusual coalition of insurers, environmentalists and fiscal conservatives is seeking major changes in the federal plan as a deadline approaches.
articles.lead_paragraph: In August, when Hurricane Harvey was bearing down on Texas, David Clutter was in court, trying one more time to make his insurer pay his flood claim — from Hurricane Sandy, five years before.

articles.headline: On YouTube Kids, Startling Videos Slip Past Filters
articles.snippet: The app has more than 11 million weekly viewers. But some disturbing knockoff videos have reached children, upsetting parents.
articles.abstract: The app has more than 11 million weekly viewers. But some disturbing knockoff videos have reached children, upsetting parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a typical night in Staci Burns’s house outside Fort Wayne, Ind. She was cooking dinner while her 3-year-old son, Isaac, watched videos on the YouTube Kids app on an iPad. Suddenly he cried out, “Mommy, the monster scares me!”

articles.headline: Following Trump’s Lead, Republicans Grow Quiet on Guantánamo
articles.snippet: As the military commission system has struggled to bring terrorism suspects to justice, civilian courts have been much more effective.
articles.abstract: As the military commission system has struggled to bring terrorism suspects to justice, civilian courts have been much more effective.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For nearly a decade, a vocal faction of Republicans have insisted that America’s civilian criminal justice system is the wrong venue for handling terrorism suspects. And for a moment last week, it looked as if President Trump might vindicate their view by transferring the suspect in the New York truck attack to military custody at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia Arrests 11 Princes, Including Billionaire Alwaleed bin Talal
articles.snippet: The sweeping campaign of arrests appears to be the latest move to consolidate the power of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the favorite son and top adviser of King Salman.
articles.abstract: The sweeping campaign of arrests appears to be the latest move to consolidate the power of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the favorite son and top adviser of King Salman.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Saudi Arabia announced the arrest on Saturday night of the prominent billionaire investor Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, plus at least 10 other princes, four ministers and tens of former ministers.

articles.headline: Commerce Secretary’s Offshore Ties to Putin ‘Cronies’
articles.snippet: Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, retained investments in a shipping firm with business ties to Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s inner circle.
articles.abstract: Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, retained investments in a shipping firm with business ties to Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s inner circle.
articles.lead_paragraph: After becoming commerce secretary, Wilbur L. Ross Jr. retained investments in a shipping firm he once controlled that has significant business ties to a Russian oligarch subject to American sanctions and President Vladimir V. Putin’s son-in-law, according to newly disclosed documents.
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire, Sasha Chavkin and Martha M. Hamilton

articles.headline: Kremlin Cash Behind Billionaire’s Twitter and Facebook Investments
articles.snippet: Leaked files show that a state-controlled bank in Moscow helped to fuel Yuri Milner’s ascent in Silicon Valley, where the Russia investigation has put tech companies under scrutiny.
articles.abstract: Leaked files show that a state-controlled bank in Moscow helped to fuel Yuri Milner’s ascent in Silicon Valley, where the Russia investigation has put tech companies under scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2010, the Russian billionaire investor Yuri Milner took the stage for a Q. and A. at a technology conference in San Francisco. Mr. Milner, whose holdings have included major stakes in Facebook and Twitter, is known for expounding on everything from the future of social media to the frontiers of space travel. But when someone asked a question that had swirled around his Silicon Valley ascent — Who were his investors? — he did not answer, turning repeatedly to the moderator with a look of incomprehension.

articles.headline: Building A.I. That Can Build A.I.
articles.snippet: Google and others, fighting for a small pool of researchers, are looking for automated ways to deal with a shortage of artificial intelligence experts.
articles.abstract: Google and others, fighting for a small pool of researchers, are looking for automated ways to deal with a shortage of artificial intelligence experts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — They are a dream of researchers but perhaps a nightmare for highly skilled computer programmers: artificially intelligent machines that can build other artificially intelligent machines.

articles.headline: The ‘Click’ Moment: How the Weinstein Scandal Unleashed a Tsunami
articles.snippet: In 1991, women wore “I Believe Anita” buttons. Now they post #metoo. Social media, famous accusers and generational change add up to a profound shift.
articles.abstract: In 1991, women wore “I Believe Anita” buttons. Now they post #metoo. Social media, famous accusers and generational change add up to a profound shift.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forty years ago this month, Ms. magazine put sexual harassment on its cover for the first time. Understanding the sensitivity of the topic, the editors used puppets for the cover image — a male hand reaching into a woman’s blouse — rather than a photograph. It was banned from some supermarkets nonetheless.

articles.headline: Gunman Kills at Least 26 in Attack on Rural Texas Church
articles.snippet: A gunman, identified by law enforcement sources as Devin P. Kelley, walked into a Baptist church in Sutherland Springs, Tex., and opened fire.
articles.abstract: A gunman, identified by law enforcement sources as Devin P. Kelley, walked into a Baptist church in Sutherland Springs, Tex., and opened fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: Read the latest on the Texas shooting with Monday’s updates.
articles.byline: By David Montgomery, Christopher Mele and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: 3% Conference Spotlights Hurdles for Women at Ad Agencies
articles.snippet: More women have risen to top creative jobs since the 3% Movement began. But they say they still have a way to go to change “Mad Men” thinking.
articles.abstract: More women have risen to top creative jobs since the 3% Movement began. But they say they still have a way to go to change “Mad Men” thinking.
articles.lead_paragraph: A young black woman walking into a first job and realizing that every member of management is an older, white male. A night out with co-workers ending early for the only woman in the group because everyone else is going to a strip club. A male executive joking to a female executive that she looks like she needs to have sex — except in more vulgar terms.

articles.headline: Saudi Crown Prince’s Mass Purge Upends a Longstanding System
articles.snippet: The move appeared to be the most sweeping shift in governance the kingdom has experienced for more than eight decades.
articles.abstract: The move appeared to be the most sweeping shift in governance the kingdom has experienced for more than eight decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A midnight blitz of arrests ordered by the crown prince of Saudi Arabia over the weekend has ensnared dozens of its most influential figures, including 11 of his royal cousins, in what by Sunday appeared to be the most sweeping transformation in the kingdom’s governance for more than eight decades.

articles.headline: A Bull Market Should Make Investors Happy. This One Isn’t.
articles.snippet: Markets are breaking one record after another, but many investors are on the sidelines. The anxiety is a contrast to the euphoria of other bull markets.
articles.abstract: Markets are breaking one record after another, but many investors are on the sidelines. The anxiety is a contrast to the euphoria of other bull markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day in September, investors with fading summer tans mingled with their brokers over a three-course lunch at Cipriani in Lower Manhattan. Stocks were soaring and they swapped market tips and touted apps that allowed them to buy Bitcoin on the golf course.

articles.headline: Tax Plan Burdens Blue-State Republicans and Their Districts
articles.snippet: Republicans hope a tax bill will lift their fortunes in 2018. In crucial states like New Jersey, with high local taxes, it could do just the opposite.
articles.abstract: Republicans hope a tax bill will lift their fortunes in 2018. In crucial states like New Jersey, with high local taxes, it could do just the opposite.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST CALDWELL, N.J. — Steve Schwartz looks like a voter who might swoon for the Republican tax plan, unveiled last week in Washington. He is a political independent who owns a company that makes windshield wipers, he describes himself as leaning “right on fiscal matters,” and he said he would benefit from the elimination or scaling-back of the estate tax.

articles.headline: Terrorism Is Faster Than Twitter
articles.snippet: Before the recent attack in Lower Manhattan, an ISIS online publication offered tips on how to use a truck for “reaping large numbers of casualties.”
articles.abstract: Before the recent attack in Lower Manhattan, an ISIS online publication offered tips on how to use a truck for “reaping large numbers of casualties.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Did you catch the third issue of Rumiyah magazine? I did — Googled my way right to it in seconds.

articles.headline: Wooing Trump, Xi Jinping Seeks Great Power Status for China
articles.snippet: Mr. Xi, the most powerful Chinese leader in decades, wants the United States to share global leadership with China as equals.
articles.abstract: Mr. Xi, the most powerful Chinese leader in decades, wants the United States to share global leadership with China as equals.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese leaders have long sought to present themselves as equals to American presidents. Xi Jinping has wanted something more: a special relationship that sets China apart, as the other great power in an emerging bipolar world.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Broadcom Targets Qualcomm in Largest-Ever Tech Deal
articles.snippet: The $105 billion takeover bid sets up a battle between two chip makers whose products touch nearly every smartphone in the world.
articles.abstract: The $105 billion takeover bid sets up a battle between two chip makers whose products touch nearly every smartphone in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Hock Tan studiously avoided the limelight, even as he built a onetime division of Hewlett-Packard into what is now Broadcom, a semiconductor maker whose chips help power the newest iPhone.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: The New York Fed Chief Is Stepping Down — but Not Quietly
articles.snippet: William C. Dudley, who is stepping down from his post earlier than expected, warned against moving too aggressively to roll back financial regulations.
articles.abstract: William C. Dudley, who is stepping down from his post earlier than expected, warned against moving too aggressively to roll back financial regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: William C. Dudley, who has been president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York since the financial crisis and became a forceful advocate for cultural change at large financial institutions, announced Monday that he will retire next year. He isn’t leaving quietly.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Air Force Error Allowed Texas Gunman to Buy Weapons
articles.snippet: The Air Force admitted that it didn’t enter Devin P. Kelley’s domestic violence court-martial into a database that could have prevented him from buying a gun.
articles.abstract: The Air Force admitted that it didn’t enter Devin P. Kelley’s domestic violence court-martial into a database that could have prevented him from buying a gun.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUTHERLAND SPRINGS, Tex. — A day after a gunman massacred parishioners in a small Texas church, the Air Force admitted on Monday that it had failed to enter the man’s domestic violence court-martial into a federal database that could have blocked him from buying the rifle he used to kill 26 people.
articles.byline: By David Montgomery, Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Jose A. Del Real

articles.headline: A Family Was Praying in a Texas Church. Then 8 Were Dead.
articles.snippet: Eight members of the Holcombe family, a group spanning three generations, died in the shooting at the First Baptist Church in Texas.
articles.abstract: Eight members of the Holcombe family, a group spanning three generations, died in the shooting at the First Baptist Church in Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUTHERLAND SPRINGS, Tex. — One minute the Holcombes were a tight-knit family praying in the tiny church on Fourth Street.
articles.byline: By Shannon Sims, Julie Turkewitz and Christina Caron
